H0.text: who pays medical bills in great britain where does the money come from to pay these bills. National Insurance Contributions

H1.text: who pays medical bills in great britain where does the money come from to pay these bills. Private Health Insurance Companies

H2.text: who pays medical bills in great britain where does the money come from to pay these bills. Charitable Organizations

H3.text: who pays medical bills in great britain where does the money come from to pay these bills. taxes

A4.text: The NHS is funded from the general budget, partially accounted for by National Insurance contributions, plus around 1% of patient charges for some services.

A5.text: In 2022/3, £181.7 billion was spent by the Department of Health and Social Care on services in England. More than 94% of spend was on salaries and medicines.

A6.text: Thus the four NHS organisations are partially funded from NI contributions but not from the NI Fund.

A7.text: National Insurance contributions form a significant proportion of the UK Government's revenue, raising £145 billion in 2019-20 (representing 17.5% of all tax revenue).

A8.text: A new tax of 1.25% on earnings, introduced in 2023, is intended to fund the National Health Service backlogs.

A9.text: In the 2010–2011 tax year, £96.5 billion was raised from National Insurance contributions, which are payable by employees, employers, and the self-employed.
